qas.question: What was Virgil Griffith focused on?
What part of the government was editing its own wikipedia page?
What was Griffith's tool designed to detect?
What did Griffith's tool help increase?
How as Griffith's wikipedia scanner viewed by wikipedia?

plausible_answers.text: edits from the United States Congress

qas.question: What was the tool not designed to do?

plausible_answers.text: edit the FBI article in Wikipedia

qas.question: What were CIA computers used to do?
How did the FBI view WikiScanner?

context: In August 2007 Virgil Griffith, a Caltech <a0_0>computation and neural-systems<a0_0/> graduate student, created a searchable database that linked changes made by anonymous Wikipedia editors to companies and organizations from which the changes were made. The database cross-referenced logs of Wikipedia edits with publicly available records pertaining to the internet IP addresses edits were made from. Griffith was motivated by the <b6_0>edits from the <a1_0>United States Congress<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and wanted to see if others were similarly promoting themselves. The tool was designed to <b7_0>detect <a2_0>conflict of interest edits<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Among his findings were that FBI computers were used to <b8_0>edit the FBI article in Wikipedia<b8_0/>. Although the edits correlated with known FBI IP addresses, there was no proof that the changes actually came from a member or employee of the FBI, only that someone who had access to their network had edited the FBI article in Wikipedia. <b5_0>Wikipedia<b5_0/> spokespersons received Griffith's "WikiScanner" <a4_0><b9_0>positively<b9_0/><a4_0/>, noting that it helped prevent conflicts of interest from influencing articles as well as increasing <a3_0>transparency<a3_0/> and mitigating attempts to remove or distort relevant facts.
